name: loaded
content:
loaded adjective
(FULL)
Add to word list
Add to word list
A loaded gun has bullets in it: It's dangerous to leave a loaded gun lying around.
[ before noun ] filled or covered with a layer of food: I want to make loaded potato skins with bacon and cheese. loaded aubergines a loaded pizza

loaded adjective
(NOT FAIR)
not fair, especially by being helpful to one person instead of another: It seems that the report is loaded in favour of the developers. loaded question
a question that has particular words chosen to suggest the answer that is wanted: A survey should avoid asking loaded questions. See also
leading question

(RICH)

loaded adjective
(NOT FAIR)
Add to word list
Add to word list
not fair, esp. by being especially helpful to one side and not the other, or (of a question) by intentionally using words that will likely produce a particular answer: The questions in this debate were so loaded that they always got the answers they expected.
loaded adjective
(RICH)
infml having a lot of money; rich: The guy never spends a dime but believe me, he’s loaded.
loaded adjective
(PUT INTO)
[ not gradable ] (of a piece of equipment) filled or supplied with something it needs to make it work : a loaded gun (= one with bullets in it)
Add to word list
Add to word list
TRANSPORT carrying goods or passengers: fully loaded barges/trucks/planes The lightest trucks in the range are less than 3,750 pounds loaded weight.loaded with sth The airliner was loaded with 20,000 gallons of fuel.
